Philip Power Papers, 1976-1998

did.abstract: Newspaper publisher, regent of the University of Michigan; collection documents Power's tenure on the University of Michigan Board of Regents, his interest in international freedom of the press, and his involvement with the Michigan Job Training Program.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection came to the library in four accessions, 1985, 1987, 1989 and 1999. Periodic additions to this collection are expected. Donor no. 7223.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Philip Power Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Philip Harwick Power was born in 1938, the only child of University Microfilms founder Eugene Power and his wife, Ann Arbor activist, Sadye Power. Earning an AB from the University of Michigan in 1960, Power continued to study philosophy, politics, and economics at Oxford University on a Marshall Scholarship, where in 1962 he earned his MA. In 1965, Power bought four unprofitable weekly newspapers, covering the towns of Livonia, Redford, Plymouth and Farmington. This initial investment laid the foundations for established the Suburban Communications Corporation, which publishes more than 60 community newspapers and six shopping guides in the Detroit, Lansing and Cincinnati areas. Power, in 1993, received the Lesher Award, the highest honor in the suburban newspaper area. An unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate's Democratic nomination in 1978, Power served the state on the Michigan Commission on the Future of Higher Education, and as chairman of the Michigan Job Training Coordinating Council. His career interests have also led him to pursuit politics on a global scale, actively defending the freedom of the press on an intergovernmental stage. After his wife's Sarah Goddard Power's death, Power was appointed regent of the University of Michigan, in June 1987. After completing his appointment in 1990, he was elected statewide to the Board of Regents, where he continued to serve until his defeat in the 1998 election. During a critical period for the university Power served on the board and consequently played a significant role in 1996, with the appointment of Lee Bollinger as President of the University of Michigan. As a publisher and a regent, Power played an active role in advocating of the amendment Open Meetings Act for university presidential searches.

scopecontent.p: The collection documents Power's tenure on the University of Michigan Board of Regents, his interest in international freedom of the press, and his involvement with the Michigan Job Training Program.

scopecontent.p: The collection begins with a biographical folder including clippings from Power's 1978 bid for the U.S. Senate nomination.

The UNESCO: Press Freedom files cover the period of 1976 to 1985 and comprise approximately 2.5 linear feet of records. These files are arranged alphabetically under four headings: analysis, documents and speeches, meetings, and organization. This series consists mostly of correspondence, press releases, articles and reports dealing with specific issues regarding UNESCO activities and the role of the mass media in world affairs. There are also some materials pertaining to Sarah Goddard Power and her involvement with UNESCO. The researcher should note that the library has a separate collection of papers for Sarah Goddard Power.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Job Training series has two subseries: the Job Training Partnership Act and Michigan Job Training Coordinating Council. Materials are arranged alphabetically within each subseries and date from ca. 1983 to 1989. This subseries consists of approximately 3 linear feet of correspondence, articles, and reports circulated while Power chaired the Michigan Job Training Coordinating Council. An addition to this series was received in 1989 and is described separately.

did.unittitle: Governor's Coordination and Special Services Plan 1983
Governor's Coordination and Special Services Plan 1984-1985
Michigan State Plan for Vocational Education 1987
Michigan Strategic Fund for Human Investment 1987
MESC Operation Plan for Fiscal Year 1984

scopecontent.p: A third series - Commission to Study Higher Education - consists of administrative records and reports dating from 1984. These files are arranged alphabetically by various sub-headings.

did.unittitle: Poll of Michigan Citizens re Post-Secondary Education
First draft of recommendation to Governor Blanchard March 1984
University of Michigan Board of Regents 1987-1998

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan Board of Regents series is comprised of reports, correspondence, newspaper clippings and meeting minutes. The series strongly details the university's 1996 presidential search and Power's advocacy for the amendment of the Open Meetings Act for university presidential search committees. The series spans Power's entire term from 1987-1998.

did.unittitle: Labor Unions-International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers 1996-1997
SACUA (Senate Advisory Council on University Affairs) 1995-1997

scopecontent.p: Although not a regent's official duty, during his term, Power organized and ran the Marshall Symposium entitled "The Information Revolution in Midstream: An Anglo-American Perspective." This series records pertain to the planning of the program as well as the event, itself. Primarily consisting of correspondence, the documents demonstrate the University of Michigan's reputation and role as a global leader in the information technology field. This series spans from the fall of 1997 until 1998.
